SourcedStatement: To learn more about having a child tested or to schedule a free test, contact your child’s pediatrician, call the Shelby County Health Department at 901-222-9582 or email them at sch.clppp@shelbycountytn.gov.
Name: Shelby County Health Department
Justification: call the Shelby County Health Department at 901-222-9582 or email them at sch.clppp@shelbycountytn.gov

SourcedStatement: To have your home tested, call the Shelby County Lead Hazard Control program at 901-222-7605 or the City of Memphis Lead-Safe program at 901-636-5323. Or, click here.
Name: Shelby County Lead Hazard Control program
Justification: call the Shelby County Lead Hazard Control program at 901-222-7605

SourcedStatement: Given the county’s long history of white flight and segregation, its oldest neighborhoods are primarily — other than Midtown — occupied by Black and brown residents. In South Memphis, for instance, about 96% of residents are Black, and about 91% of homes were built prior to 1978, according to the U.S. Census Bureau.
Name: U.S. Census Bureau
Justification: according to the U.S. Census Bureau

SourcedStatement: The map below shows which Memphis ZIPs contain the most homes built before 1980, according to Census data.
Name: Census

SourcedStatement: To find out if your individual home was built before 1978, check Realtor.com or the Shelby County Assessor of Property website.
Name: Shelby County Assessor of Property website
Justification: check Realtor.com or the Shelby County Assessor of Property website
